entry.title: Error messages from MES system API's for deleting components in S/4 Public Cloud production orders
entry.content:
We are using a third-party MES system in combination with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Our manufacturing environment involves complex products with production orders that have long lead times and consist of a large number of components.

Current Process: After production orders are released, they are distributed to the MES system, which then takes the lead for order management and execution.

Issue: We frequently have components with item category N (non-stock items) that are procured directly for specific production orders. Due to the complexity and long lead times, components sometimes need to be changed or deleted during production.

Since the orders are distributed to MES, these changes cannot be made directly in SAP. However, when we attempt to make these changes from our MES system using the API_PRODUCTION_ORDER_2_SRV API, we encounter the error message: "System status DISB is active".

We have also tried alternative approaches, such as:

  • Setting the component quantity to zero
  • Setting the ReservationIsFinallyIssued indicator

Both approaches result in error messages.

Question: Is there an alternative solution to modify or delete components from production orders that have been distributed to MES while the DISB status is active?

entry.title: Parallel processing Error with call transaction
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I have a program that sends invoices to Sefaz and waits for a few minutes to receive approval (this is a government service in my country). It currently does this via CALL TRANSACTION. Today, we send thousands of invoices, and with the program running in the background, it’s taking too long. For this reason, parallel processing was suggested.

So, I stored the CALL TRANSACTION inside an RFC function using STARTING NEW TASK, and this works when debugging. However, if I run the program directly or via a job, it shows as completed but does not send the invoices or receive the response.

Is there any limitation with CALL TRANSACTION inside an RFC using STARTING NEW TASK that prevents it from sending data to Sefaz? Or could it be something else?

Thanks

entry.title: SAP TM - Load Plan Print Configuration in SAP TM
entry.content:
SAP TM - Load Plan Print Configuration in SAP TM

Load plan printing is a critical functionality in SAP Transportation Management (TM) that enables organizations to create detailed visual representations of how cargo should be loaded into vehicles. This comprehensive guide will walk you through the complete configuration process and best practices for implementing load plan printing in your SAP TM environment.

Understanding Load Plan Printing

Load plan printing in SAP TM provides both hierarchical table views and 3D visual representations of cargo loading arrangements. This functionality is essential for warehouse operations, drivers, and logistics coordinators who need clear instructions on how to load and unload vehicles efficiently,

The system supports printing for various document types including road freight orders and container units, with enhanced capabilities available from SAP S/4HANA 2021 onwards.

The exist form for print out is available in the Spool Transaction SP01, once you Create a Load Plan for Freight Document:

The exist form for print out is available in the Spool Transaction SP01,:

The Printout contain all the information about product, package material, Quantity, include the 3D image:

 

Configuration Steps

  1. Define Load Plan Printing Layout

Navigation Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Transportation Management → Basic Functions → Load Planning → Printing → Define Load Plan Printing Layout

Activity: /SCMTMS/V_LPPL
Transaction Code: SM30

This foundational step establishes the basic structure for your load plan printouts. Here you define the layout framework that will be used across your organization.

  1. Configure Load Plan Printing Layout

Navigation Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Transportation Management → Basic Functions → Load Planning → Printing → Configure Load Plan Printing Layout

Activity: /SCMTMS/C_LPPLF
Transaction Code: SM30

In this configuration step, you specify detailed settings and enable various fields within your load plan printing layout. This includes determining which information fields should appear on the printout and how they should be formatted.

  1. Define Load Plan Printing Profile

Navigation Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Transportation Management → Basic Functions → Load Planning → Printing → Define Load Plan Printing Profile

Activity: /SCMTMS/V_LPPP
Transaction Code: SM30

The printing profile is where you configure comprehensive settings including:

  • Load plan printing layout reference
  • Company logo integration
  • 3D image settings and parameters
  • Layout specifications for 3D load plans
  • Number of printing sequence steps
  • RFC destinations for authentication and service connectivity
  • Parallel processing profiles for 3D image generation
  1. Assign Load Plan Printing Profile

Navigation Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Transportation Management → Basic Functions → Load Planning → Printing → Assign Load Plan Printing Profile

Activity: /SCMTMS/C_LPPPA
Transaction Code: SM30

The final configuration step involves assigning your defined load plan printing profiles to specific business document types, such as freight order types. This ensures that the appropriate printing configuration is automatically applied based on the document type.

Enhanced Features and Capabilities

3D Load Plan Visualization

Modern SAP TM implementations support advanced 3D load plan visualization, providing realistic representations of cargo placement within vehicles, this feature requires:

  • Subscription to SAP Enterprise image creation service
  • Proper RFC destination configuration
  • Complete resource master data with dimensional information

Batch Processing

From SAP S/4HANA 2022 onwards, batch printing capabilities are available, Access this functionality through:

Navigation Path: Logistics → Transportation Management → Administration → Background Processing → Print Load Plan

Container Unit Support

Enhanced printing capabilities for container units include hierarchical table printing with optional 3D images, accessible directly from the transportation cockpit,

Prerequisites and System Requirements

Version Requirements

  • Basic Load Plan Printing: Available in earlier TM versions
  • Enhanced Features: SAP S/4HANA 2021 and later,
  • Batch Printing: SAP S/4HANA 2022 and later,
  • Container Unit Printing: SAP S/4HANA 2021 and later

Master Data Requirements

Ensure comprehensive master data setup including:

  • Complete resource capacity details (internal length, width, height)
  • Physical properties (tare weight, cargo body distance)
  • Axle group information
  • Load planning settings and rules

3D Image Prerequisites

For 3D visualization capabilities:

  • SAP Enterprise subscription for image creation services
  • Proper RFC destination configuration
  • Parallel processing profile setup

Printing Load Plans

Manual Printing Process

Load plan printing can be initiated through the output management functionality:

  1. Navigate to the relevant business document (freight order or container unit)
  2. Access the Output Management tab
  3. Execute the (Un)Loading Instruction action

Transportation Cockpit Integration

For container units, load plan printing can be triggered directly from the transportation cockpit, providing seamless integration with daily planning activities.

Advanced Configuration Considerations

Load Plan Status Management

SAP S/4HANA 2021 introduced enhanced load plan status management across the document chain, this allows:

  • Display of load plan status for referenced capacity items
  • Direct status modification in successor documents
  • Improved transparency across the entire document chain

Manual Load Plan Creation

The system supports manual load plan creation for specific scenarios,

  • Non-palletized products requiring specific loading sequences
  • Combination resources with drag-and-drop functionality between trailers
  • Custom loading arrangements based on operational requirements

Troubleshooting Common Issues

Layout Configuration Errors

If you encounter the error "Enter a layout for the load plan" when modifying Transportation Cockpit layouts, verify that load plan layout configuration is properly maintained in your page layout settings.

3D Image Generation Issues

For 3D image problems:

  • Verify SAP Enterprise subscription status
  • Check RFC destination connectivity
  • Validate parallel processing profile configuration
  • Ensure complete resource master data

Best Practices

  1. Standardize Layout Designs

Develop consistent layout standards across your organization to ensure uniformity in load plan documentation.

  1. Leverage 3D Visualization

Implement 3D load plan visualization for complex loading scenarios to improve accuracy and reduce loading errors.

  1. Integrate with Mobile Devices

Consider mobile-friendly formats for drivers and warehouse personnel who access load plans on handheld devices.

  1. Regular Testing

Conduct regular testing of print configurations, especially after system updates or master data changes.

  1. Training and Documentation

Provide comprehensive training to end users on interpreting and utilizing load plan printouts effectively.

Conclusion

Load plan print configuration in SAP TM is a powerful feature that significantly enhances operational efficiency in transportation management. By following the systematic configuration approach outlined in this guide, organizations can implement robust load plan printing capabilities that support their specific operational requirements.

The enhanced features available in newer SAP S/4HANA versions, including 3D visualization and batch processing, provide additional value for organizations looking to optimize their transportation operations. Proper configuration, combined with comprehensive master data maintenance, ensures that load plan printing becomes a valuable tool for improving loading accuracy and operational efficiency.

Thank you and regards!

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Mastering Test Preparation in SAP Cloud ALM: A Step-by-Step Guide to Bulk Test Case Upload
entry.content:
Managing test cases effectively is one of the most critical yet often underestimated aspects of SAP implementations.

Whether you're executing a greenfield S/4HANA project or migrating from ECC, the ability to efficiently prepare, organize, and track thousands of test cases can make or break your project timeline.

SAP Cloud ALM's Test Management capabilities, particularly the bulk test case upload feature, offer a practical solution we've successfully deployed across multiple customer implementations.

Understanding SAP Cloud ALM's Test Management Architecture

SAP Cloud ALM provides a centralized, cloud-native platform for managing the entire testing lifecycle. The solution is designed to be easy to consume while remaining open to support all products—cloud and on-premise, SAP and non-SAP systems.

The platform delivers comprehensive test orchestration capabilities including scope definition and management, manual functional testing, automated functional testing with full requirements traceability, execution monitoring and sign-off workflows, and reporting and auditing for compliance.

For test automation, SAP Cloud ALM integrates with cloud-based automation providers, including the Test Automation Tool for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and Tricentis Test Automation—giving organizations flexibility in their automation strategy.

Requirement-Driven Implementation: The Entity Model

One of SAP Cloud ALM's greatest strengths is its coherent, requirement-driven entity model that connects all project artifacts across the implementation lifecycle. Understanding this model is essential for effective test management.

The implementation follows SAP's Activate methodology phases: Discover → Prepare → Explore → Realize (with Sprints) → Deploy → Run. Within this framework, a structured hierarchy of entities ensures complete traceability.

At the project level, Cross Project Entities provide the foundation: Roles, Systems, Landscape Assignments, Tags, and Workstreams. These are valid across all projects and provide consistency.

The Project Scope combines Process Scope with Requirements. During the Prepare phase, Project Tasks focus on "Create Scopes," establishing Scope definitions that contain Processes. In the Explore phase, "Conduct Fit to Standard" activities validate these processes against requirements.

The Realize phase is where testing becomes central. Requirements spawn User Stories (with Sub-Tasks for granular work tracking), and critically, User Stories connect to Test Cases within the Test Plan. When defects are discovered during test execution, they link directly back to the Test Case, maintaining full traceability. Features aggregate the testing status for deployment decisions.

Documents can be attached throughout the model, providing supporting evidence and documentation. The Deployment Plan organizes work into Releases, allowing phased go-lives with clear scope boundaries.

This architecture means that when a defect is found during UAT, you can trace it back through the Test Case → User Story → Requirement → Process → Scope chain, providing complete visibility into impact and priority.

Manual Test Preparation: The Foundation

Before diving into bulk uploads, it's essential to understand how test cases are structured in SAP Cloud ALM.

Each test case is built by defining the scope of relevant business activities to be included, creating the overall test case structure through numerical ordering of these activities, and expanding each process activity with specific test actions.

Each test action contains a title describing the action, instructions explaining how to execute it, and expected results defining the success criteria. Additional tabs allow you to assign requirements, ensuring traceability is maintained from the start.

The General Information tab provides context including scope (inherited from the solution process), solution process details with flow diagrams, and tags for categorization. When preparation is complete, you set the test case status to "Prepared," making it visible in the Test Execution Overview.

Bulk Test Case Upload: The Efficiency Multiplier

For large implementations with hundreds or thousands of test cases, manual creation isn't practical. The bulk upload feature transforms test preparation efficiency. Here's the workflow we've refined across multiple projects.

First, access SAP Cloud ALM through your tenant URL and navigate to Implementation. Then select Test Preparation from the navigation menu. Click "Upload Test Cases" to initiate the bulk process, and select the corresponding Scope for your test cases. Click Browse to locate your prepared template file—this is an Excel template with your test cases already structured according to your team's standards. Click Upload and confirm the action. Finally, review the uploaded test cases to verify accuracy.

The key to successful bulk uploads lies in template preparation. Work with your functional teams to ensure test cases follow consistent naming conventions, have clear step descriptions, and include proper scope assignments before upload.

Analytics: Visibility Into Your Testing Progress

SAP Cloud ALM provides robust analytics for test management across four key areas.

The Summary Page serves as the central entry point for all testing information and activities. Cards and filters can be managed through variants to create test-focused views, and tags enable granular filtering when needed.

Test Execution Analysis lets you monitor execution progress with different chart types and provides direct navigation to the Test Execution Overview for detailed drill-down.

Defect Report Management tracks defect resolution progress through visual representations and offers navigation to defect details for investigation and resolution.

Traceability Views answer critical questions like "Which requirements are ready for production deployment?" The selection criteria examine requirement status (in testing), feature status (in testing), all user stories set to "Ready," and all test cases set to "Approved."

When these criteria are met, teams can navigate to the requirement's feature to set status to "Ready for Deployment" and proceed with transport deployment to production.

A Tool Amplifies Your Capabilities—Nothing More

As I often remind project teams: a fool with a tool is still a fool.

SAP Cloud ALM's Test Management capabilities are powerful, but they don't replace the fundamentals.

You still need clear test strategies aligned with business risk, well-trained testers who understand both the tool and testing principles, defined processes for test case creation, review, and maintenance, and executive commitment to quality as a project priority.

The bulk upload feature saves enormous time, but only if your test cases are well-designed. The analytics provide visibility, but only if your team maintains data discipline. The traceability features enable confident go-live decisions, but only if requirements are properly linked from the start.

Practical Recommendations

Based on our implementation experience, we recommend starting with template standardization by establishing Excel templates that match your organization's testing standards before beginning bulk uploads.

Invest in scope definition since proper scope setup is foundational—test cases inherit scope from solution processes, so get this right early.

Use tags strategically as they enable powerful filtering in analytics, so plan your tagging taxonomy before test creation begins.

Finally, leverage traceability views for go-live decisions since they provide objective, auditable evidence of testing completeness.

SAP Cloud ALM Test Management delivers significant value for organizations navigating S/4HANA implementations.

The combination of structured test preparation, efficient bulk upload capabilities, and comprehensive analytics creates a foundation for quality that scales with your project complexity.

entry.title: Re: Output Management - How to send emails to mail-addres...
entry.content:
Hello @SCHNEIDERT 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the information you provided and from my understanding, the Cloud V2 only shows contact email from the Account Contact relationship. The Output Management on the other hand normally reads email from the BP address, so basically there is a mismatch.

My suggestion is to add a logic because there is not standard customization that changes Output Management. Therefore, enabling BAdI APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS in Output Parameter Determination and implementing the BAdI to read the relationship-based email (through a CDS view on BP relationships and addresses) and return it as the email recipient should provide the solution. Doing it this way will help you keep a single source of truth and still use Output Management without changing standard integration behaviour

See the following for more information: 3331087 - Sample implementations of custom logic: Addition of Email Recipients - SAP S/4HANA Cloud

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Question of Full Loading Large CDS VIews from S/4 HANA: Problems and Solutions
entry.content:
Introduction

It’s no secret that many companies today have large, or even massive, datasets in S/4 HANA systems that need to be uploaded to SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere or SLT. A prime example of this is the CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData, which consume data from the ACDOCA table. There are known cases where the ACDOCA table exceeds 10 billion records. This article will discuss the problems that arise when transferring such large datasets and explore potential solutions.

In my previous article, I mentioned that the first step in the initial data load procedure is the calculation of "Access Plans". This is necessary to speed up the data loading process by parallelizing the processes. Each access plan is a specific range of records, defined by the object’s key fields. The size of this range is set during start of replication and varies for different scenarios. For example, in a BDC scenario, the default size of a single portion is 500 megabytes, for SAP Datasphere Replication Flows size portion is 30 megabytes. Since one access plan consists of 100 portions, the size of an access plan is approximately 50 gigabytes for BDC scenario and 3 gigabytes for Replication Flows. 

Note: above mentioned size is the size of data representation in ABAP runtime.

The Access Plan Calculation process itself consists of two phases: pre-calculation (aka delimitation) and calculation of access plans. The pre-calculation process divides the entire dataset into large chunks, which are known as "access plans". The calculation process reads the data within the calculated boundaries, divides it into portions, and writes these portions to a special intermediate buffer. Immediately after the calculation of one access plan is complete, a transfer process for that access plan is initiated. Optimization in  the access plan calculation process is achieved because, after the pre-calculation phase, each access plan is calculated in a separate process, and the number of these processes is limited only by service settings, system power, and allocated computing resources.

The main problem for very large CDS Views arises during the pre-calculation process. During pre-calculation, the process reads all sorted key fields of all records from the CDS View once to determine the boundaries of the access plans. This is where problems can occur due to the limitations imposed by the HANA database. There are several limitations:

- First, HANA DB imposes a limit on the number of records returned in a single query – it cannot exceed 2 billion records.
- Second, there is a parameter that defines the memory size allocated by HANA DB for a single session. The query can exceed the memory allocated for one session.
- Third, overflow can also occur if HANA DB does not build query plans optimally enough.
In such cases, the object gets stuck in the "Error in Delimitation Process" status, which you can observe in the DHADM tool, in the "Access Plan Calculation Overview" section. In this case, you need to choose the optimal solution strategy and restart the object upload.

So, what solutions are available to address these problems? First, I will briefly list them, and then I will describe each approach in more detail:

  1. If a session runs out of memory, the simplest and most obvious solution is to increase the session memory limit provided to each session.
  2. If the CDS View contains simple left outer join or simple select from a table with more than 2 billion records, then database partitions are used during pre-calculation process.
  3. If the main table of the CDS View is partitioned, it may be possible to use special hints that will help HANA DB build query plans efficiently.
  4. If previous recommendations do not help, it is suggested to use the ranges functionality, provided in DHADM tool.

Unfortunately, there is no universal solution to these problems; each option has its pros and cons, involves certain complexities in implementation, and has some limitations. You must independently decide which approach will be the most optimal for a given dataset to solve the problem.

 

1. Increasing the Session Memory Limit Size in HANA DB

The official documentation on the SAP Help Portal contains detailed information on "Setting a Memory Limit for SQL Statements": 
On the portal, you will find recommendations for the allocated memory sizes and how to change the parameter value.
 
However, it should be kept in mind that increasing the session memory limit can only help if the number of records in the CDS View does not exceed 2 billion records.
Although this method helps in most cases, it's still has limits, it may have to be combined with the solution described below.
 
Practical Example:
The buffer size was set to 341 GB. And although, according to expert assessment by HANA DB specialists, this value is very large, this size was still not sufficient to execute the query from the I_GLAccountLineItemRawData CDS View.
It is potentially possible to continue increasing the parameter value further, but it is still recommended to look for other ways to solve the problem.
 

2. Utilizing Physical Partitioning of the Main Table at the HANA DB Level

This option provides a solution when the CDS View contains more than 2 billion records. Usually, such CDS View is built on partitioned table. Using physical partitioning the pre-calculation process divides the table into large blocks. 
The calculation of Access Plans will be performed within each partition separately, independently of each other. By the way, in this case, the pre-calculation process will also be accelerated because it is performed in several parallel processes.

Picture 1. Access plan calculation concept

Please note that pre-calculation will only use the partitions created for the main table. The role of the main table must be described in the dataExtraction annotation within the CDS View or can be determined automatically in simple cases. Example CDS View: I_GLAccountLineItemRawData:

      dataExtraction: {
        enabled: true,
        delta.changeDataCapture: {
          mapping:
            [
              {
                table: 'ACDOCA',
                role: #MAIN,
                viewElement: ['SourceLedger', 'CompanyCode', 'FiscalYear', 'AccountingDocument', 'LedgerGLLineItem'],
                tableElement: ['rldnr', 'rbukrs', 'gjahr', 'belnr', 'docln']
              }
            ]
         }
      }

Code 1. Example of CDS Annotation with declaration of MAIN table


For example, for the ACDOCA table, there is SAP Note 2289491, which provides best practice recommendations.

Nevertheless, there are examples where this does not help, and the error persists. In this case, you can try supplementing the solution with the first option (increasing buffer) and/or the next option using DB hints.

 

3. Utilizing HANA DB Hints

 
If you are the owner of the CDS View (and have control over the code), you can use HANA recommendations and apply database hints directly in CDS View to help the database build query plans more efficiently. Or you can apply hint to existing SQL statement.
 
@Consumption.dbHints: ['USE_HEX_PLAN']
An article from the official SAP Help Portal containing detailed information on "Performance Aspects of Specific Features" where you can find a description of the hint.
 
This method is recommended to be used in conjunction with table partitioning. This can help save memory and stay within the allocated buffer for a single session.
 
 
Practical Example:
In continuation of the first practical example, it's not possible to apply a hint to the SAP owned CDS View which cannot be changed.
In such case it is necessary to find the hash value of pre-calculation query (for example, using the search in DBACOCKPIT->Performance->Expensive Statements). The pre-calculation statement looks like:
 
SELECT /* Contains Native SQL */ "SOURCELEDGER" , "COMPANYCODE" , "FISCALYEAR" , "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" FROM /* Entity name: I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS */ "IFIGLACCTLIR" "A" WHERE "MANDT" = ? AND "FISCALYEAR" = ? AND EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM "ACDOCA" PARTITION (10) WHERE "ACDOCA" . "RCLNT" = ? AND "ACDOCA" . "RLDNR" = "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" AND "ACDOCA" . "RBUKRS" = "A" . "COMPANYCODE" AND "ACDOCA" . "GJAHR" = "A" . "FISCALYEAR" AND "ACDOCA" . "BELNR" = "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" AND "ACDOCA" . "DOCLN" = "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" ) ORDER BY "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" , "A" . "COMPANYCODE" , "A" . "FISCALYEAR" , "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM"
 
And execute the following command:,
 
ALTER SYSTEM ADD STATEMENT HINT ( USE_HEX_PLAN ) FOR STATEMENT HASH '2e23331ec91cbc6b803aa477ec4538d9';
 

4. Usage of Range Conditions Functionality

Even so, it may happen that all the previously described methods do not solve the problem. There is another method, which is very similar to partitioning - Range Conditions in DHADM transaction.

Ranges are the division of the entire dataset into parts, same to database partitions, but it is performed only for pre-calculation during initial load process. The advantages of this approach are:

- Ranges can be defined independent from database partitions.
- Ranges can break down data into smaller portions than partitions.
- When using ranges, the SQL query has a simpler form, and HANA DB significantly optimizes this type of query.
Here, I want to describe several questions that arise when using Range Conditions.

a. Are Range Conditions applied only during Initial Load?
Yes, ranges are applied and used only for the initial snapshot load. During the delta phase, ranges no longer play any role.

b. Is it possible to use Range Conditions for data filtering?
Yes, it is possible, but strongly not recommended.
First, based on the previous point - filters based on ranges will only be applied for the initial load. Delta data will not be filtered. And secondly, you must always remember that the ranges are defined the in scope of current client and CDS View. This means that if you want to load the same CDS View with different "filters", you will not be able to. The same set of "filters" will always be used. To filter data, it is recommended to use the mechanisms provided by various scenarios. For example, SLT and Datasphere offer the ability to defined filters when setup replication. The BDC scenario does not provide filter capability.

c. What operations are supported in the definition of range conditions?
All standard logical comparison operations, as well as AND/OR and BETWEEN.
Do not forget to define ranges correctly, especially open boundary range conditions. There should be no gaps in the definition. It is recommended to make the boundary intervals open to avoid data loss. For example:

 interval 1: key1 < 1000
 interval 2: 1000 <= key1 < 5000
  ...
 interval N: key1 >= 100,000

Code 2. Example of range boundaries

During save Range conditions will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user. 

d. Who should define and maintain ranges, and what is the optimal strategy in defining ranges?
We cannot give you any particular recommendation how to define range conditions. Each client independently defines the ranges according to their needs and data content.
Analyze your data structure, look at which key fields do not change very often so that you can use them as a basis for dividing the data, and see how evenly the data is distributed across these values.
By the way, in the first option, you can use the same conditions that are proposed for database partitioning. Since, as already mentioned, another simplified form of the SQL query is used for ranges, there is a possibility that these ranges will solve the problem.

e. How to create Range conditions?
One of the drawbacks is that ranges must be defined manually, range by range, using the DHADM UI.

Add new range via DHADM UI

Picture 2. How to add new Range manually via DHADM UI

However, by installing SAP Note 3670148, a simpler way to support ranges is offered, which also allows you to migrate ranges between systems.

You need to create an file with the specific structure. The file’s structure should follow the specifications outlined in the note. The descriptor file can contain range conditions for multiple CDS Views.

After creating such a file, it must be uploaded to the system via the DHADM UI. During the upload, all ranges will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user! Attention: when uploading ranges, the previous definition will be overwritten. After uploading, you can change and correct the ranges using the built-in UI or by changing the source file to repeat the upload.

If you have defined or corrected ranges in the test system, you can export all ranges to a file and transfer them to the production system.

[
	{
		"cdsviewname": "I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA",
		"ranges": [
			{
				"id": 1,
				"condition": "FiscalYear < '2021'"
			},
			{
				"id": 2,
				"condition": "FiscalYear >= '2021' and FiscalYear < '2022'"
			}
		]
	}
]

Code 3. Example of JSON file for CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData

Upload/Download ranges

Picture 3. Upload or download ranges for one or several CDS Views


Similar to partitions, access plans will be calculated for each range separately. Similar to the option with partitions, the pre-calculation process will also be performed in parallel for each range.
The most important rule: all operations must be performed before the start of the load. Existing subscriptions do not take ranges into account in the pre-calculation process.

entry.title: Re: GRC integration with SAP HANA - Guide
entry.content:
Important: In total there must be two delivery units (DU) installed on the target database (#HANA)

SELECT * FROM _SYS_REPO.DELIVERY_UNITS ORDER BY DELIVERY_UNIT ASC

Should return:

HCO_GRC_PI
SAP_PI_GRC

The delivery unit SAP_PI_GRC is missing in the target database when GRC throws errors like:

Could not execute 'DROP PROCEDURE "SAP_PI_GRC"."Get_Role_Actions"'
SAP DBTech JDBC: [328]: invalid name of function or procedure: Get_Role_Actions: line 1 col 29 (at pos 28)

entry.title: Re: Error importing data
entry.content:
@Ganjos , Looks like you have Data Access configured on the model. You can check it in Model settings. Check what dimensions are used to define the Data Access. In those dimensions you will have Read and Write column which controls are read and write access to those members of the dimension. The end user does not have access to the members you are loading the data to. You need to ensure the end user has write access to all members you are trying to load the data for in all secured dimensions.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

In Private Cloud, these apps/transactions allow us to enter individual tax codes in the “Tax” tab. This way, users can combine N different tax codes within the same document.

However, in Public Cloud this behavior is not allowed (please see attached screenshots). The system forces us to use combined tax codes instead of individual ones.

Could you please help us understand:

  • Whether this behavior in Public Cloud can be configured/changed to allow multiple individual tax codes in the Tax tab (similar to Private Cloud)?

  • Or if there is any correction, SAP Note or roadmap item planned to support this behavior?

As additional context, in Argentina most customers are registered under “Convenio Multilateral”, so they usually require many tax combinations.

Best regards,

Blas Rosello, SAP Consultant

entry.title: Re: Deep Link to PCC
entry.content:
Hello, 

there isn't any PCC home page, but you can access each PCC app using a direct link.

The direct link should be built like the following:

https://<host>:<port>/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*>/index.html?sap-client=<client>&sap-ui-language=<language_code>

where:

<host>:<port> : to retrieve that information, you can use trx SMICM: Goto-->Services

/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*> : you should indicate the PCC service. See the whole list in the attached link:

Use Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

or

Activate Payroll Control Center SAPUI5 Applications | SAP Help Portal

<client> : client of your system

<language_code> : your preferred language

In addition, you could configure FIORI launchpad (see below link) where you can define specific tile for each PCC service: 

Configure Fiori Launchpad Tiles for Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: Welcome SAP-RPT-1! What is it? How can you try it out?
entry.content:
SAP announced SAP-RPT-1 at TechEd 2025 in Berlin. What is it good for, and how can you try it out? In this blog post, I'll walk you through the announcement and show you how to get started, both in a no-code approach and in Python.

 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT stands for Relational Pre-Trained Transformer which SAP wants us to pronounce as 'rapid one'. To make sure this is pronounced correctly, they even write out phonetic transcription [ˈræpɪd] [wʌn] - so no excuses here 😉.

If you are looking for a quick executive summary, check out Philipp Herzig's Keynote presentation which explains that RPT-1 is a new type of AI model that is optimized for making predictions on tabular data. Unlike LLMs which generate the next word (token) for a text sequence, RPT-1 predicts the next field in a table row. Putting this in a practical example, Philipp mentions that RPT-1 can predict, for example, delivery times or customer churn, essentially replacing traditional ML models like XGBoost or Random Forest with a single RPT-1 model.

For now, SAP-RPT-1 comes in 3 flavors:

  • SAP-RPT-1-Small: A small model optimized for super-fast predictions
  • SAP-RPT-1-Large: A larger model optimized for highest accuracy
  • SAP-RPT-1-OSS: An "open source" version for everybody to learn (Github / Huggingface)

The way Philipp talked about the OSS version, I assume that this is also the version which is available in the RPT Playground, your starting point to try out RPT-1 in a no-code environment.

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in the RPT Playground

The easiest way to get started with RPT-1 is the RPT Playground. SAP has prepared some data, but you can also upload your own tabular data (CSV files) and use RPT-1 to make predictions on it. The trick for making predictions with RPT-1 is to mask the field you want to predict with [PREDICT]. Once you click on the "Predict" button, RPT-1 will fill in the masked field with its prediction.

While SAP's prepared use cases work well, you'll get a better sense of RPT-1's capabilities by trying it with your own data. To help you get started, I've prepared the example data from the coding tutorial (allowing you to predict sales groups from Product, Price, Customer, Country) in a CSV file for you to download. You can easily modify this file in Excel (or any other editor), save as CSV and try your own data in the RPT Playground. If you'd prefer to start simple, try out the example CSV file I have prepared for you.

If you're not a coder, simply skip the coding section and jump right to the conclusion.

 
 

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in Python

If you want to get your hands dirty with code, I have prepared a Jupyter notebook that shows in detail how to use RPT-1.

Prerequisites

Assuming you have access to the RPT Playground and that you have downloaded the Jupyter notebook, you need to fetch your access token from the bottom of the playground page.

To avoid storing your credentials in the notebook, copy & paste the token (RPT_TOKEN) into a .env file in the same folder where you have stored the Jupyter notebook. It should look like this:

RPT_TOKEN="eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1" # truncated, your token is a lot longer

Once you've done that, you're ready to run the notebook.

 
 

Preparing Test Data

Here's the test data in the format RPT-1 expects:

 
payload = {
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [
            {
                "name": "SALESGROUP",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]"
                # "task_type": "classification" or "regression" can be specified here if needed
            }
        ]
    },
    "index_column": "ID",
    "rows": [
        {
            "ID": "1001",
            "PRODUCT": "Tablet",
            "PRICE": 599.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "TechStart Inc",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1002",
            "PRODUCT": "Standing Desk",
            "PRICE": 325.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "Workspace Solutions",
            "COUNTRY": "Germany",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1003",
            "PRODUCT": "Workstation",
            "PRICE": 1450.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Enterprise Systems Ltd",
            "COUNTRY": "Canada",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1004",
            "PRODUCT": "Laptop Pro",
            "PRICE": 1899.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Business Corp",
            "COUNTRY": "UK",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1005",
            "PRODUCT": "Gaming Laptop",
            "PRICE": 1250.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Digital Ventures",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1006",
            "PRODUCT": "Smart Watch",
            "PRICE": 299.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Gadget Store",
            "COUNTRY": "Australia",
            "SALESGROUP": "Consumer Electronics"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1007",
            "PRODUCT": "Ergonomic Chair",
            "PRICE": 445.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Office Outfitters",
            "COUNTRY": "France",
            "SALESGROUP": "Office Furniture"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1008",
            "PRODUCT": "Storage Array",
            "PRICE": 3500.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "CloudTech Systems",
            "COUNTRY": "Singapore",
            "SALESGROUP": "Data Infrastructure"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1009",
            "PRODUCT": "Network Switch",
            "PRICE": 175.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "ConnectIT",
            "COUNTRY": "Japan",
            "SALESGROUP": "Networking Devices"
        }
    ]
}
 
 

For better readability, here is the data in table format:

 
import pandas as pd

sample_data = pd.DataFrame(payload["rows"])
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
#sample_data.to_csv("sample_data.csv", index=False)
 
 

As you can see, we have 4 attribute columns: Product, Price, Customer, Country. Our target column is the Sales Group. Therefore, the sales group is masked in 2 lines with the value [PREDICT], so that RPT-1 can demonstrate that it can fill in the missing values.

 
 

Running the predictions

To run the predictions, we will use the requests library to send an HTTP POST request to the RPT-1 API endpoint. The request will include our test data and the authorization token.

 
#!pip install python-dotenv # install if not already installed
 
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

load_dotenv()

auth_token = os.getenv("RPT_TOKEN")
 
import requests

url = "https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict"

headers = {
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {auth_token}"
}

response = requests.post(url, json=payload, headers=headers)
 
 

Analyzing the results

Let's take a look at the results returned by RPT-1. Here are the predictions in the raw JSON format:

 
import json

data = response.json()
preds = data["prediction"]["predictions"]
print(json.dumps(preds, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False))
 
[
  {
    "ID": 1001,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Enterprise Solutions"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "ID": 1002,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Office Furniture"
      }
    ]
  }
]
 
 

Let's merge these predictions back into the tabular format to see the results more clearly.

 
preds_df = sample_data.copy(deep=True)

preds_df["ID"] = preds_df["ID"].astype(int)

for pred in preds:
    row_idx = int(pred["ID"])
    predicted_value = pred["SALESGROUP"][0]["prediction"]
    preds_df.loc[preds_df["ID"] == row_idx, "SALESGROUP"] = predicted_value

preds_df
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSAEnterprise Solutions
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermanyOffice Furniture
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

For comparison, here is the original sample data before predictions:

 
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

Conclusion

As we can see, RPT-1 has filled in the missing sales groups based on the patterns contained in the context, i.e., the other entries. Essentially, the non-masked rows serve as few-shot examples that RPT-1 uses for in-context learning. This behavior is comparable to an LLM imitating examples you provide in a prompt. Here's a simple example of such a prompt:

Write an executive summary for the Lord of the Rings.

Here is an example for Romeo and Juliet:
Boy and girl fall in love, in the end they both die.

If you try this prompt, you might get a result like this:

Guy inherits ring. Walks a lot. Destroys it.

Similarly, RPT-1 uses the non-masked rows as examples to predict the masked values. The key difference is that RPT-1 does not semantically generate text, but it predicts the most likely value for the masked fields based on the patterns it has learned during training.

Of course, the example we used is very simple, and it will be interesting to see how RPT-1 performs on more complex datasets. For now, I hope you are all set to try SAP-RPT-1 with your own data. Happy experimenting!

entry.title: New version 8.6 of the SAP Cryptographic Library with quantum-safe cryptography and FIPS 140-3 mode
entry.content:
Overview

The SAP Cryptographic Library enables applications like SAP S/4 HANA to support security protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security), SNC (Secure Network Communication), SSF (Secure Store and Forward) and X.509. While the library already includes "modern" cryptographic algorithms such as those based on Elliptic Curve Cryptography, these were until now all part of the group of "classic" algorithms. 

Most "classic" algorithms for asymmetric cryptography are vulnerable when a cryptographically relevant quantum computer becomes reality. This might have an impact even today if attackers record encrypted communication and store it for later decryption ("harvest-now-decrypt-later"). 

Quantum-safe cryptography in the SAP Cryptographic Library

The new version 8.6 of the library enables support for a quantum-safe TLS 1.3 handshake. When the library is installed on an SAP NetWeaver ABAP system and TLS 1.3 is used to establish a connection, then a hybrid ECDHE-MLKEM key agreement based on X25519MLKEM768 takes place. ML-KEM is a new, quantum-safe algorithm for key encapsulation, which was already standardized as FIPS-203. This makes it impossible, even for a quantum computer, to determine the session key and decrypt the session communication. 

New FIPS 140-3 certification of the FIPS crypto kernel

FIPS stands for Federal Information Processing Standard. A FIPS certification is required by US public sector agencies, healthcare, and financial industries, and many more. FIPS 140-3 validates the proper implementation of the algorithms in cryptographic modules.

The FIPS crypto kernel is a dedicated module in the SAP Cryptographic Library that was recently certified as compliant with FIPS 140-3. The certificate is available from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST): Certificate #5093.

For SAP Application Server ABAP and SAP HANA, SAP note 2180024 explains the configuration steps that are required to switch the SAP Cryptographic Library to FIPS mode.

Release Details

The release note "3685428 - Fixes and features in CommonCryptoLib 8.6.2" has now been published. More information about the SAP Cryptographic Library is available in "1848999 - Central Note for CommonCryptoLib 8 (SAPCRYPTOLIB)".

entry.title: Re: Hi Experts,I need your guidance. We are working in SA...
entry.content:
Yes, instead of relying on 309 material-to-material transfer, stage-wise SFG inventory updates using production order–based postings (movement 261/101) or custom goods receipt processes with batch management is possible, which allow system-generated batches and capture process losses more naturally than 309 transfers. But I am not sure, whether production order creation is possible since your post says not fully configured.

So the work around would be

  • Movement 501 (GR without PO) → Create stock for the new material with a fresh batch.
  • Movement 201/202 (issue to cost center) → To reflect consumption/loss of input material.

Together, these mimic stage-wise consumption and creation without PP orders.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creati...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn

Yes,  grouping relationships involving the same BP into one set of 100 can significantly help avoid the locking conflicts you are currently facing. Considering creation happens in parallel background jobs, if the same BP appears across different parallel jobs, it can easily cause deadlocks or serialization issues, especially since SAP_WFRT attempts to lock and activate those records simultaneously.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Manage Inventory Count and Adjustment in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Welcome! In this blog, you’ll see how the physical inventory counting and adjustment process works in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
We’ll also explore the latest capabilities of the new app “Manage Physical Inventory Item List”, which brings more visibility, speed, and simplicity to your inventory operations.

Our goal is to help you use these functionalities with confidence — and we’d love to hear from you!
If you have experiences, questions, or suggestions, feel free to leave a comment at the end of this post.

Before You Start: What You Need to Know

The full process is described in detail in the test script BML – Physical Inventory – Inventory Count and Adjustment, including prerequisites, system access requirements, and business conditions.

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013/2508/SolP/BML?region=DE

One optional (but very valuable) preliminary step is setting up Situation Handling. With it, the system can automatically trigger notifications, messages, or even emails when a counting difference occurs — helping your team react faster and more accurately.

Let’s take a look at what you can configure.

  1. Configure Situation Handling (optional but recommended)

To use Situation Handling, the scope item 31N – Situation Handling must be activated.

Manage Teams and Responsibilities app

In this app, you can:

  • Create, edit, copy, and delete teams
  • Assign a global team ID
  • Enable or disable team status directly from the overview
  • Assign team owners responsible for the team setup
  • Assign functions to multiple members at once

  • Create team owners who are responsible for a team header, responsibility definitions, team members and their functions.

  • Maintain responsibility definitions for teams.
  • Replace a team member (Business Partner ID) across teams

Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a624a4a6d1d8473eb95fb42660127cfe/bdc5c6a612a043ed913e22159b5a4f42.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

Learning journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/managing-teams-and-responsibilities

Manage Situation Types app

Here, you define when and how the system should notify the responsible users.

Steps:

  1. Open Manage Situation Types
  2. Look for MAN_PHYSICAL_INVENTORY_MONITOR
  • If not available, create it using the test script as a reference

You can define:

  • Trigger conditions
  • Recipients
  • Notification layout (Launchpad message + email)

  • Scheduled jobs for automated notifications

Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/60748ea9f37d4692912578b698aaefee.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

  1. Starting the Physical Inventory Process

Step 1: Create the Physical Inventory Document

Using the Create Physical Inventory Document app, you can create:

  • A single document for one material
  • A mass creation for multiple materials

You can also enable Set Posting Block (under Additional Header Data).
When activated, no postings can be made for that material until counting is completed.

If a user tries to post during counting, the system will show an error message similar to the image below:

You can additionally schedule the creation of Physical inventory documents, splitting them by: Storage bin, Material, Material group.

Step 2: Print the Inventory Document

Open Manage Physical Inventory Documents app, search for your document, and select Background Print.
You can view the generated PDF under:
Output Management → Display Details

Step 3: Perform the Physical Counting

Once you have printed the documents, your team performs the physical count at the shop floor.

P.S.: You have the possibility to edit this PDF file, for example by adding your company’s logo. Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/bd637484dc2f47a5a9071157f388ccd8.html

  1. Post Counting Results

Step 4: Enter Counting Results

In the Manage Physical Inventory Count app, click the Edit icon to enter the results.

You can:

  • Enter quantities manually
  • Upload results using an Excel template provided by SAP

Thresholds for tolerances can be configured using SSCUI 106788 – Manage Tolerances for Physical Inventory Differences.
If a difference is detected and Situation Handling is configured, the responsible user will automatically be notified.

Step 5: Reviewing the Results
With the new Manage Physical Inventory Items app, you can perform the following actions:

  • View counted quantities
  • View identified differences
  • View the cost impact on stock
  • Perform mass postings or mass recounts — speeding up the process

You can also filter inventory items using multiple available dimensions.

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F8634')/S35

Step 7: Analyze the Inventory Results

Use the Physical Inventory Analysis app to get a complete overview of your inventory performance.
For example, you can summarize differences by plant and material.

Through Navigate to, you can access more analysis options such as:

  • Analyze Stock in Date Range, where you can compare beginning and ending stock values and generate useful insights.

We Want to Hear From You!

As mentioned at the beginning, your feedback is extremely valuable.
Feel free to leave your questions, comments, or suggestions — let’s improve this process together!

Useful links:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/76984c36687f413391531bed71e51259.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/add-a-reason-to-the-physical-inventory-document/qaq-p/14267467

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/physical-inventory-goods-movement-types-701-702-and-711-712/qaq-p/12317683

entry.title: HCM Brasil - Redução do IRRF - Lei 15.270
entry.content:
Olá pessoal, 

Acabamos de entregar uma importante atualização para o sistema de folha de pagamento brasileiro, implementando a redução do Imposto de Renda Retido na Fonte (IRRF) conforme a Lei Nº 15.270. 

Esta nova funcionalidade proporciona redução significativa no imposto de renda para funcionários em faixas salariais específicas, aplicando o benefício após o cálculo normal do IRRF. 

 A solução está disponível através das seguintes SAP Notes: 

  • 3684446 - IRRF Reduction - New wage types
  • 3687982 - Prerequisite objects for SAP Note 3687983 
  • 3687983 - BRIR - New IRRF Reduction - Payroll changes 

Principais Funcionalidades 

Cálculo Automático da Redução 

O sistema agora aplica automaticamente a redução do IRRF baseada nos seguintes critérios: 

  • Salários de R$ 0 a R$ 5.000: redução de até R$ 312,89 
  • Salários de R$ 5.001 a R$ 7.350: redução calculada pela fórmula 978,62 - (0,133145 × base tributável) 

Novas Rubricas para Controle

Foram criadas novas rubricas para rastreamento completo da redução: 

  • Rubricas de Base Tributável: 
    (total da base tributável para aplicar na tabela de redução) 
    /TI1 – Rend. Tributável
    /TI2 – Rend. Tributável (Férias)
    /TI3 – Rend. Tributável (13º) 
  • Rubricas de Redução IRRF:
    (registram o valor da redução aplicada)
    /TR1 – Redução IRRF
    /TR2 – Redução IRRF (Férias)
    /TR3 – Redução IRRF (13º) 
  • Rubricas de IRRF Antes da Redução:
    (mantêm o valor original do IRRF sem o desconto aplicado)
    /TG1 – Tributo IRRF sem redução 
    /TG2 – Trib. IRRF s/Red (Férias) 
    /TG3 – Trib. IRRF s/Red (13º) 

 Exemplo Prático 

Para um funcionário com salário de R$ 5.000: 

Componente 

Antes da Lei 

Com a Lei 15.270 

Rubrica no sistema 

Rendimento tributável 

R$ 5.000,00 

R$ 5.000,00 

/TI1 

INSS 

R$ 509,60 

R$ 509,60 

 

Base de IRRF 

R$ 4.392,80 

R$ 4.392,80 

 

IRRF Calculado 

R$ 312,89 

R$ 312,89 

/TG1 

Redução Lei 15.270 

- 

R$ 312,89 

/TR1 

IRRF Final 

R$ 312,89 

R$ 0,00 

/401 

Com essa implementação, garantimos que os funcionários recebam todos os benefícios fiscais previstos na nova legislação, mantendo a conformidade total com as exigências legais.  

Gostou desse post? 
Dê um Like e compartilhe o conteúdo com seus colegas. 

Fiquem à vontade para deixar um feedback, comentário ou pergunta sobre este Blog post no espaço abaixo. E não esqueçam de seguir a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para ficarem ligados nas últimas notícias. 

Um abraço, 

Anderson Bueno
Time de HCM Brasil

entry.title: Re: ERROR 80101
entry.content:
Hi @mo-shabeer ,

Note that in most SAP Data Services landscapes, the Designer and Job Server components run on separate machines, and in some cases, the Job Server operates on Linux while the Designer runs on Windows. This distributed architecture creates important considerations for file access. When a job needs to access local files, the file path must be accessible from the Job Server machine and not just the Designer machine. The issue you are facing is a common issue that occurs when occurs when the file path is valid and accessible from the Designer machine but the same path is either inaccessible from the Job Server machine, or the path exists but the required file is not present on the Job Server

Regards Joe !

entry.title: SAC Import job fails in first step (gather data)
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We are building a new SAP Analytics Cloud for planning solution and have an import job that has previously run without issues for weeks. We are extracting data from an S/4HANA on prem system (QA environment) to an SAC Dev tenant, so nothing is productive at this point. Suddenly the job started failing in the first step  (or couldn't be created, if we tried to create a new and identical import job). We are using oData service UI_FINS_GLACCOUNTFLOW to fetch data from the GLAccountBalanceFlow view.

After playing around with fields and filters in the job, it has been established that the Profit center and Cost center fields are causing the job to fail. If these fields are omitted, the job completes successfully. However, these fields are critical for the solution.

The error messages in SAC are many but fairly bland and there are no entries in the SAC monitor (trace).

The problem is not caused by missing authorizations, as even if the SAC user gets SAP_ALL in S4, the job still fails. Does anyone have any suggestions on what to investigate next in order to identify the root cause? As I said, the job ran fine for weeks and the suddenly started to fail.

Also, running the job importing data from S/4 DEV environment runs without issues, so the issue appears when trying to import from  S/4 QA.

I appreciate any inputs.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: SAP Data Services Job "Hangs" Occasionally. Requires...
entry.content:
@dunncrew

to abort the job, if you are on Linux, you can create a script that monitors the al_engine using a combination of various utilities and comparing the results after some time and if there is no al_engine activity for some time you can consider the process hanged and terminate it. 

# Process state, context switches, memory usage 
cat /proc/$PID/status 

# I/O activity (read/write bytes) 
cat /proc/$PID/io | grep -E "(read_bytes|write_bytes)"; 

# CPU time (user + system) 
cat /proc/$PID/stat 
# Real-time snapshot (CPU%, state, memory) 

top -p $PID

For windows i recommend searching the windows equivalent to the above commands.

you would need to come up with a way to grab the al_engine process ID once they are launched so you can start grabbing the metrics from the commands above. You can also think of better ways to monitor

entry.title: BiWhy – Web Intelligence Processing Server (WEBI) Memory
entry.content:
Disclaimer:
BiWhy is available again for FREE to everyone on biwhy.net

BOBJ Sizing Guide:
‘Enable Memory Analysis’ is now unchecked by default when you perform a new installation from BI 4.2 onwards... We now recommend this is disabled as your default setting, enabling the process to use as much memory as it needs and without the need to reclaim memory or generate any related error due to memory limits becoming breached.

But I strongly recommend always keeping it enabled to protect the host memory from being exhausted by WEBI.

 

The exhaustion can happen for two reasons: 

Memory leak.

I once saw WEBI consume 100 GB during an Excel export. I am sure this specific issue was fixed long ago, but nobody can guarantee that the code is fully leak free.

Real load:

  • Multiple concurrent users
  • A few users running very large reports
  • A combination of both

 

Think about Memory Thresholds the same way you think about the Java Xmx parameter.

If thresholds are reached, the system will handle the situation gracefully. In the worst case, WEBI will be restarted, which impacts only the users assigned to this specific WEBI.
If thresholds are not set, the same scenario may cause the entire host to run out of memory, which can lead to system-down situations or worse. What do you prefer?

Here is a conservative formula for calculating memory allocation for WEBI:
WEBI_MAX = Available_RAM – Sum of Xmx (APS and others) – 2 GB for OS – 2 to 4 GB for CMS (or more, depending on actual usage) – Xmx for Tomcats if they run on the same host – other major memory consumers on the server.

My recommendation: set thresholds high enough that they are never reached during normal operation, but still low enough to avoid endangering the host memory.

Why does the Sizing Guide recommend switching off Memory Analysis?

I do not know for sure, but the most likely reason is related to thresholds configuration.
Thresholds must be customized for each system. They cannot be set correctly by default, because default values would be either too high or too low.

BOBJ administrators need to understand what Lower, Upper, and Maximum Thresholds mean and how to connect the warning messages seen by end users to these configured parameters, so they can adjust thresholds or upscale the system instead of opening incidents.

A possible improvement on the SAP side would be to explicitly state in warning messages that they originate from the Memory Analysis configuration.

Threshold meaning from Admin Guide:
If this property is enabled then the following properties will be active and recognized by the server:

  • Memory Maximum Threshold
  • Memory Upper Threshold
  • Memory Lower Threshold

If the Memory Lower Threshold limit is reached, the server swaps out inactive documents onto the hard disk allocating additional memory for the documents which are active. Each user is allowed to have up to one active document instead of Maximum Documents per User.

If this Memory Upper Threshold is reached, the following server actions will take place in order to free resources and protect the server:

  • The server will reject new connections and new client calls. Only the option to Save Web Intelligence documents will be allowed. Users that request an action will receive a Server Busy message, and they will be notified that they should save any pending changes.
  • The server will turn on system cleanup to free enough resources so that the amount of allocated memory is below the limit set by the Memory Upper Threshold property.
  • The server tries to close read-only documents.
  • If not enough memory was freed during system cleanup then the server will begin to close documents that are in Editing mode. The server will begin to close documents based on the LIFO protocol; the most recent active document will be purged from memory first. The server will continue to close documents until a safe level is reached; this level is based on the following calculation: Memory Upper Threshold - (20%*(Memory Upper Threshold)). For example, if the Memory Upper Threshold property is set to 4.5GB then the safe level would be: 4.5GB - 20%*4.5GB = 3.6GB
  • The server cannot close documents when a client call is running. Any document that is refreshed or exported to another format or any other time consuming operation will not be closed when the server reaches this threshold. If the server cannot recover enough memory and is still above the Memory Upper Threshold, it restarts.

If the Memory Maximum Threshold limit is reached, all current operations abort. All client calls will be terminated. Once the a call terminates, the corresponding document will be closed.

Or shortly:

When the server's process memory is above the Memory Upper Threshold, the only operation that is allowed is saving documents.

When the process memory is above the Memory Maximum Threshold, all operations stop and fail.

Screenshots:

Content:

  • BOBJ Metrics: cumulative WEBI usage of 430 GB, with recommendations on WEBIs per host
  • BOBJ Metrics: individual WEBI usage reaching 74 GB
  • OS-level monitoring: cumulative WEBI allocation of 450 GB

Here is a production system with 800 sessions. Cumulative WEBI memory usage reaches 430 GB, with individual WEBI processes using up to 52 GB.
You can see multiple WEBI servers per host. SAP recommends one WEBI per host, or two for failover if the system has only a few WEBI nodes. Although in the past we observed during VTOs that in some cases multiple WEBIs perform better, for simplicity and to reduce communication overhead I recommend fewer WEBIs unless there is a clear reason to do otherwise.

Here is a VTO run with 1,400 sessions, with a WEBI process consuming up to 74 GB

OS-level monitoring shows that on a system with only 46 active sessions, WEBI on two nodes cumulatively consumes about 450 GB.
However, I do not believe this reflects real memory usage – it is rather allocated memory. This is mainly due to the customer running 10 WEBI servers per host, with Memory Analysis switched off and 1 TB of RAM available per processing node.

entry.title: Attachments / Folder Permissions
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We are using SAP Business One 10.0 (HANA). An attachment path has been defined in Administration → System Initialization → General Settings → Path.

The attachment folder is maintained as a shared network folder.

Problem Details:

  • When the attachment shared folder is configured as Read-Only, users are not able to attach files from any SAP Business One transaction.

  • The system throws an error while attaching documents.

  • If Full Control permission is given to the attachment folder, users are able to attach files successfully.

  • However, with Full Control permission, users are also able to delete or modify other users’ attachments, which is not acceptable from a security and audit perspective.

Requirement / Question:
We want users to:

  • ✔ Upload (attach) files from SAP Business One transactions

  • ❌ Not delete or modify existing attachment files of other users

Please guide me, SAP Business One specific settings, or best practices (for Windows / file system level) to control attachment deletion?

 

Thanks & Regards,

Abdul Fasith

entry.title: How to analyze error message inconsistent amounts F5 704 in Migration Cockpit?
entry.content:
Dear SAP S/4HANA Experts,

during the migration of customer open items using the migration object “FI – Accounts receivable open item”, one open item is not being migrated. Instead, the following error messages occur:

  • “Inconsistent amounts”
  • “Error in document: BKPFF $ CDACLNT275”

When I analyze the relevant open items in the SAP ERP source system using transaction FBL5N (Customer Line Items), document 6293930 contains two line items:

  • one line item with H Debit/Credit Ind. and a negative amount of -1,065.07 EUR
  • another line item with S Debit/Credit Ind. and a positive amount of 57.55 EUR

Both line items are listed identically in the XML template file as well as in the staging table.

However, only the line item with S Debit/Credit Ind. and the positive amount of 57.55 EUR is migrated into the SAP S/4HANA test system.

The source structure of the migration object “FI – Accounts receivable open item” does not contain a field for the Debit/Credit Ind.. Therefore, I assume that the Migration Cockpit derives the Debit/Credit Ind. of an open item solely based on the sign of the value in the field “Amount in doc curr.”. We are migrating the customer open items into an SAP S/4HANA test system in which no user exits, such as EXIT_SAPLV60B_002, EXIT_SAPLV60B_008, or similar enhancements, have been implemented.

At present, I am unable to clearly interpret the cause of these error messages from a functional perspective.

Could this be a misunderstanding on my side, or is this a limitation or issue within the Migration Cockpit?
What solution or recommended approach would you suggest in this case?

Kind regards,
Emal Rahman

entry.title: Re: Custom Adobe Form How to Print 7 Outputs with Differe...
entry.content:
Hello @kranti_babhulkar

Answer on how to detect the copy number:

Since your backend only sends one data payload and you are repeating the subform manually, you need to use the instanceIndex method provided by Adobe LiveCycle scripting to determine the current iteration index. Basically, you need to use JavaScript inside the repeated subform; inside the header label field of the repeated subform. Make sure the script runs on form ready or initialize and not on calculate, so it executes once per iteration.

Answer to Line item not repeating inside each copy:

This seems to be a structure issue in your form layout and probably your line items subform is outside the repeating block. Which probably makes it render only once. I suggest you move all layout into the repeatable subform. Make sure the entire invoice layout (Header section, Line items table and Totals) is place inside the repeatable parent subform.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance: Known Issues
entry.content:
This blog covers latest information and known issues for the SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance, delivered via SAP Cloud Appliance Library (SAP CAL).
The overview blog for the appliance can be found here.
The known issues for older appliance releases are here: 2023 / 2022 / 
If you would like to ask a support question, please do so in the SAP CAL Community.

Technical Topics

Initial system performance after instance creation or re-activate

When you create an instance or suspend / re-activate it, the system performance will be slower, especially within the Fiori Launchpad. Also, the first click on a Fiori tile will be significantly slower. This is due to initial caching in the system and will become faster if you continue working.
Other performance tuning tips are:

    • Choose the cloud provider location nearest to you (for good network latency)
    • The demo users contain a relatively large number of roles and Fiori tiles. You can copy these demo users in TCode SU01 and adapt accordingly e.g. remove roles, create your own roles / Fiori catalogs, or personalize the Fiori launchpad (see also the SAP Fiori Rapid Activation demo guide on the appliance demo page).

Note: SGEN has been performed to pre-compile ABAP coding.

Initial demo users (S4H_.... and others) are locked

This works as intended and helps to increase the security of newly created appliances. Please log on with DDIC or SAP* and unlock them. They usually still have the password Welcome1, hence, it is recommended to assign a new (strong) password after unlocking them. Another alternative is copying the default users to your own user IDs.

Transport system (STMS) is not configured by default

Please check the SAP standard documentation how to configure the transport system in a new system.

Issues with specific business scenarios

Fiori Content Manager (transaction /UI2/FLPCM_CUST): ABAP dump when assigning a catalog to a role

Symptom:
In /UI2/FLPCM_CUST > Catalog tab > Search for a catalog > Click “Show usage in roles” (upper pane) > Click “Assign role” (lower pane) >  Choose a role and click OK > Runtime error “OBJECTS_OBJREF_NOT_ASSIGNED_NO” occurs

Solution / Workaround:
Before starting the above sequence, switch once from the catalogs tab to the roles tab and then back to the catalogs tab; then the error does not occur.

Data Migration Cockpit

The demo scenarios for "direct transfer" are not available with the initial release of the SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance.

entry.title: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data set using more than one value of this property
entry.content:
Hi,
 
We need to filter a data entity (sap.crm.api.caseservice) using the filter conditions input of a "Get record collection" activity in Build Apps. For this, we use the following formula in the Formula Editor:
 
{type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds[0].accountTechnicalId}]}
 
appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds is the variable where we store the values needed to filter the data set. It is a list of objects with one property (accountTechnicalId).
 
The formula works well, but as you can see, we're filtering using the first occurrence of the array only ([0]), which results in showing the records filtered on this value only. We've made countless tests but they're always returning errors, for instance:
 
{type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds}]}
 
So the question is: using the Formula Editor, is there a simple way to apply the filter using all the values stored in the variable? Else, is there some sort of "for each" activity or should we create a loop or use a JS script in the logic canva? Basically, the goal here is to apply a filter on a single property of a data set using one or more values of this property.
 
Thanks a lot for your help on this, we're stuck on the problem for quite some time now and we need to implement this urgently for a demo to a client next Thursday...
 
Best regards,
 
LM.

entry.title: Re: Regulatory Content Service vs 3rd Party Data Provider...
entry.content:
Hello

reading between the lines: you are using SAP S/4 HANA "on premise" version. If you would like to user the new prodcut "Product Compliance" you should use S/4 HANA version 2025. If you are not on this release: You should do an upgrade

If you are using a SAP Cloud variant. Much better: but you should the update/upgrade to the most current version if the cloud version if it comes in place and you shold not wait.

For more information: Check SAP Marketplace regarding the official statements of SAP regardng "Product compliance" (and the corresponding Roadmap of this new solution).

Second: as explained in the parallel answer: you have two options to go for:

Either you use the  SAP Regulatory Content service

or you neeed to provide a different company providing similar services.

I strictly recommend to check the options existing and to look to the future (at least until 2029 !!). So any other content provider (in comparising the SAP service) should support as well any upcoming enhancment of Product Compliance. 

With best wishes

C.B.

entry.title: Re: EasyDMS Question related to Q system refresh from P
entry.content:
Hello

your problem is well known. You need to separate the "refresh" of data and the refresh of documents.

The data is now "copied" to Q:but not the documents.

There are many options to go for. It depends on "acceptance" criteria which you would like to go for.

If you accept (and you should to this) that the "documents" from "Q" are not the same as from "p": why not just generate new documents in Q?

Simple and easy

There are other options to go for.  But you should use the simplest one as anything else wil increase the "complexity" of the copy of "P" to "Q".

C.B.

entry.title: BW vs. Datasphere (DSP) & SAC
entry.content:
From a functional and development perspective, SAP BW and the combination of Datasphere (DSP) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) represent two different generations of SAP’s data & analytics stack.

  • BW is feature‑rich and comes with many out‑of‑the‑box capabilities: tightly integrated data warehousing, mature modeling, and predefined mechanisms for enhancements and reporting.
  • DSP/SAC provides a leaner programming and configuration set, which often requires a “do‑it‑yourself” approach: more scripting, more custom logic, and more architectural decisions on the customer side.

However, DSP/SAC are actively and rapidly evolving. Each release brings new features—and sometimes new issues, especially in SAC—but the overall trajectory clearly indicates that DSP/SAC are the strategic future. Over the long term, the flexibility, cloud‑native approach, and continuous innovation of DSP & SAC are expected to outgrow and eventually surpass BW in capability and relevance.

How-To implement BW functionality in DSP/SAC:

Architecture DSP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030

BW Security like in DSP/SAC: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-like-authorizations-in-datasphere-dsp/ba-p/14153918

Generic-like extraction into DSP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-delta-extraction/ba-p/13699391

BW to DSP extraction using ODP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-bw-odp-delta-via-replication-flow/ba-p/13739830
